p: Considering this scenario, the evolution of the vaccine development against VL was relatively rapid. While no licensed vaccine against human Malaria is currently available, in spite of being a disease described in the fifth century BCE, four licensed veterinary vaccines are available against VL, a disease known only since 1903. Besides these veterinary vaccines, there is one live human Leishmania vaccine licensed in Uzbekistan ( 78). In fact, a mixture of live and dead L. (L.) major parasites has been licensed for leishmanization in areas with high-risk populations. The leishmanization technique was developed by Professor Adler, and this live vaccine was exhaustively used in Israel ( 9, 78). Although most field studies focus on human cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL), there have been no clinical trials of first-generation vaccines using species of Leishmania causing VL ( 79).
